While I don't dispute the idea that both Jack & Rose would have been able to share the space on the DoorFrame, I still would argue that if they did so, as the MythBusters demonstrate in this video, they would have both been partially submerged with 20% of their bodies exposed to the water and would face severe hypothermia, or at the very least major frostbite. Remember: during the actual sinking of the Titanic, the water was −2 °C, which is lethally cold and would kill most people in 15 minutes of exposure, and that's if your body didn't go into immediate shock. And even then, several of the people pulled out of the water would still succumb to hypothermia (only 6 people pulled out of the water survived). Hell, one of the collapsible boats during the event was partially submerged with a foot of water, and several of its occcupants died of hypothermia in the night. So personally, I doubt that, realistically, Jack & Rose would have both survived on that frame had they shared it.

The problem with the life jacket solution in this scenario is of course that the Titanic went down in 1912. At the time, life jackets weren't exactly... Waterproof. That's gonna sound weird, but it's true. They were made from water-resistant materials like cork! However, that cork could only repell the water for so long, and once water seeped into the material, it would become waterlogged and much heavier. It was actually known for killing people! If I recall my numbers correctly, the Cork life preservers of the 1910's gave you about 20 minutes of effortless flotation, saving you valuable energy that you needed to stay afloat later. But after those 20 minutes were up, the life preserver would actually have negative bouyancy, and your best chance at survival would have been to take it of.

In other words, after 20 or so minutes, the life vest itself would have sunk the door.

Everyone talked about Jack, Rosie, etc, but did you guys know the Violinist scene from the movie, where the musicians kept playing, WAS REAL? The short version of the story: when the musicians of the ship noticed they were doomed, they talked and noticed their role as humans - and musicians - was to soothe people's souls. So, they decided to play until the end, trying to bring comfort to the others. Well, all of them died and, later, the violin of the violinist, who was the leader of the band, was retrieved from the Titanic remains. It was all greyed by the years below water. It had one (or two?) strings left. I saw an article and a picture of it sometime around 5 years ago. The violin went to an auction and was sold for a small fortune (I can't remember how much, but if I'm not mistaken it was around 2 million dollars). The violin was regarded until today as a token of true altruism, love for Humanity and selflessness.

Came here after watching a video by Jill Vill, who debunks the Mythbusters' test with the following points:
1. Their test failed to consider the effects -2˚C salt water has on the body and the effects of hyperthermia. The body stiffens up, making it hard to move, much less swim. Uncontrollable swimming exhausts the body as the organs shut down.
2. The drift wood isn't a door, but a 50Ib door frame. Add the separate weights of Jack and Rose, they couldn't stay on together. The difference in weight mattered and the Mythbusters didn't consider that. The space was there for both of them, but the weight was the troublesome part.
3. Rose was an upper-class lady with her life made for her (thus no reason for her to know survival skills) and Jack was a third-class uneducated amateur artist; they didn't have the luxury of the internet or advanced degrees in science to construct the buoyancy device the Mythbusters used to increase their own buoyancy. We're taking about people from 1912 vs. scientists in the 21st Century.
4. If they did try to alternate who was on the driftwood, their bodies still couldn't accommodate fast enough for them both to survive. You can't just keep hopping from freezing cold to less cold. Their body temperatures would have spiked.

The only chance for survival was either Rose got on the boat when she had the chance or they could have found another piece of drift wood.

A lot of people have been saying that jack and rose (I think?) would have died anyway because they were panicking and in the middle of the atlantic in freezing waters. This is a fair point: The MythBuster is not as accurate as could be. However, the point of this mythbuster is "would Jack have survived if rose had shared the door?" The decision of whether to share the door or not is gone. I would say that this MythBusters, even though it got some things wrong, "compensated" for them with other aspects of it's recreation. Firstly, yes, the ability for Jack and Rose to stabilize in these conditions would be tougher, given their circumstances. However, given that Rose is a female who would be significantly lighter than the cast members, and the fact that Jack is a young man,  I would say that they would be a lot lighter, and that their bouyancy would thus increase, decreasing the time and effort it would take to stabilize, compensating for their situation.

If you look the stages of hypothermia, Rose and Jack did exactly what they should have done.
In freezing water:


First minute: you hyperventilate and need to focus on breathing and getting your head above water.


Next 9 minutes: the last chance you have to use your muscles and swim/ move as your blood starts to slow. You start to lose dexterity immediately, but may be able to make larger motions. (One sailor described not being able to tie on a lifejacket due to this dexterity loss). You need to use this time to get your body in a position where your airway will stay open/out of the water, even after your muscles stop supporting your weight (As Rose did by getting on the door, and as Jack did by attempting the same). It is good to let your arms freeze to a surface to hold you up (as Jack did by holding Rose's hand once he realized it was too difficult for him to get on the door).


Minute 10- minute 60: You try to conserve heat while keeping your head above water, and as much of you out of the water as possible, but you can barely move. You would not be able to grip onto the door or use your core muscles to stabilize the door. Having a lifejacket on will actually help you conserve heat at this point. So will holding hands. Rose deciding to turn over and lay on her back was wise, as it kept her airway further from the waves.


Minute 61: Death or unconsciousness if you're lucky.


It took them a couple minutes to even find the door... I don't think they had time to figure out the life jacket thing before they became physically incapable of getting back on the door. Staying in the freezing water to tie the life jacket on actually decreases both of their chances at survival. Jack had a stable position leaning on the door that kept his airway clear for breathing. That is the best thing he could've done. If he had instead been tinkering around trying to tie on a life jacket, or worse trying to squeeze onto the door with Rose that was clearly imbalanced and easy to flip, he would most likely have been in a less stable position and possibly underwater when he lost the ability to move his arms and legs, and it would've been too late for him to climb back to the door edge.


Source: http://www.shipwrite.bc.ca/Chilling_truth.htm

Problems with this:

1. The Mythbusters definitely weigh much more than Jack and Rose
2. Colder water is more buoyant than warmer water, colder water molecules are closer together (more dense)
3. The salinity of water is also an important factor, higher salt content increases density which increases buoyancy
4. As well as the material the door is made out of, a lighter wood is more likely to carry their weight compared to a heavier wood

At the end of the day, they realistically both would have died from hypothermia. The door argument misses this point completely.

Here's the thing: it doesn't matter whether there was enough room on the door or not. The problem in that scene was getting onto to it. Now if the water is at 0 degrees (32 for the Americans), or near 0, as obviously, it is not frozen, then it would take anywhere between 15 - 30 minutes to become delirious, then unconscious. Obviously, your body will not wait till you're sitting in freezing cold water for fifteen minutes to shut down; it happens gradually. So by the time that they had gotten to the door, they would have already been nearly delirious, since Jack had lost consciousness only minutes later. Therefore, they wouldn't have been able to think about buoyancy. Also, taking into account the struggle that it took for the MythBusters to get on the door, in perfectly good conditions, neither of them would have been able to get onto that door while half frozen, and in water. In fact, this is proven to be true in the movie when it takes all of both Jack's and Rose's strength just to lift Rose onto the door. So yes, the door could probably hold the both of them, but the conditions were way different. And besides, let's not forget this is a story; the writer wrote it how he wanted to write it. If he wanted Jack dead, then Jack would have died, regardless of how big the door was. If Jack had lived, this movie may not have gotten as much popularity as it had. So let's not ruin a perfectly reasonable ending when there are tons of movies out there with considerably more prominent plot holes.

There's a flaw with the Maguyver upgrade that they did (if this was to been applied during the sinking of the HMS Titanic)
When the HMS Titanic sank, the life vests (in those days) used cork as the material to make the user float. It would work for a while. Like an hour or some such.
After being in water after a certain amount of time, the cork would begin to soak up water and turn the life vest into a brick vest.

Cameron already talked about this. There was enough buoyancy for both to get on, however there wasn't enough to keep them both out of the water. It doesn't seem like it but when you are laying down and your body is 2 or 3 inches in freezing water, with freezing air coming down on you, you are dead in an hour or two. The water naturally carries your heat away at a very rapid rate. It's why you'll see scuba divers in the bahamas wearing wet suits even though the water is right below luke warm. In fact and this is the biggest point cameron has spoken about.

Water takes your heat away 25 times faster than air. So they would have been soaked in ice cold water with no protection from the water or air because their clothes are wet and they'd be dead in an hour or so.

Okay I feel like by the time they made it to the door, with all of the chaos from rescuing Jack from the Master at Arms' room, escaping the rapidly rising water, trying to save that child and ultimately nearly drowning after that guy dropped the keys to open the locked gate, making it up to the deck, getting Rose to a lifeboat, reuniting after she jumps back onto the ship, being shot at by Cal, going back up on deck, racing to the stern of the ship as it begins tilting, holding on for dear life as the boat tips up and then as it plummets back down after cracking in half, holding on AGAIN as the ship goes vertical once more, swimming up to the surface against the powerful current of a several-ton ship as it's sucking freezing, ice-cold water downwards, nearly being swarmed by other drowning patrons, and then FINALLY finding the fucking door, Jack and Rose are probably dead-exhausted and burnt out from adrenaline and shock. But in the movie they we're in freezing water and in the middle of the ocean where the water wasn't as calm as in this video.

1. It takes quite a bit of strength, time and physical coordination to untie, remove, position and retie a lifejacket, especially when both your hands are totally numb, your muscles have only 10 minutes before completely seizing up because they depend on being a minimum temperature to work, and your heart is weakened for that same reason yet its job is even further increased because the cold is literally congealing all your body fluids.
2. Both Jack and Rose probably only had the energy, time and mobility for one attempt to get onto the raft. Rose was successful. Jack sadly not. How much more sad would it have been if they'd somehow got the lifebelt tied onto the raft and created enough buoyancy but Jack simply didn't have the strength or mobility left to climb onto it?! And how scary it must therefore have been for Rose getting OFF that raft to swim to the dead officer and blow his whistle for rescue - one chance and one chance only, with a very limited timeframe, to survive!
3. So much for successfully 'holding it steady' in daylight, in warmer waters, with no drifting wreckage or thrashing, panicking people on either side...see point 2; they only had one chance to make it work. Maybe Jack just didn't want to risk Rose's life like that on his account.
4. All bodies and their limits of endurance are slightly different. Without the insulation of a lifejacket it may have been that both Rose's and Jack's bodies would have given out before the lifeboat got to them, even if they had both been on the raft and even if their core temperatures hadn't yet dropped to a temperature at which it was certainly impossible to survive - as happened to many atop collapsible B and in collapsible A. The deciding factor in that kind of cold is the amount of body fat (provides some insulation) and the strength of a person's heart - not everyone has an equally strong heart or an equal percentage of body fat. Again, how sad would it have been if Rose had seen the boat coming back, turned to Jack and simply found him frozen beside her?! And in climbing off the raft to get to the whistle she dislodged his body which sank as a dead-weight, as it did in the film, thus eliminating all chance of his revival and survival. Part of me thinks this might actually have been a better way to show his death - to show how utterly unavoidable it was.
5. Technically over 1,500 deaths were needless, not just Jack's! Had they stopped for the night, had they not tried to slow down and just turned hard over when they saw the iceberg, had there been enough lifeboats and better lifeboat procedures, had someone woken up the operator on the Californian just in case he could detect something across the ether when they saw odd stuff happening with a ship on the horizon - or even put the apprentice operator (who was awake and seeing everything) on in his plce, they would have heard the distress calls and steamed to the rescue.
6. You can hardly blame Jack and Rose for not thinking of doing that when they were so spent and probably foggy-brained, amid a panicking throng where the panic probably rubbed off and it took all they had to stay calm and focussed.

truth be told, the idea that jack could had fit on the door is plausible, and I totally agree that he could have lived. but unfortunately, jack's fate isn't up to a piece of wood, its up to the writer. James Camron wrote the story as how he envisioned it. and apparently he wanted to write a "tragic love story". after all, it all takes place on a tragic ship. honestly, I think he debated whether or not to kill off jack in the story as he was writing it. he repeatedly put jack in life threatening situations were he could die but decided it wasn't the right time. he wanted jack's death to be as sad and tragic as possible, wanting the audience to fall in love with the character so the impact of his death would effect the audience on a deep level. the titanic was a tragic accident that took many lives, I believe James Camron was trying to show just how real and heart breaking the event was.               so "could jack have fit on he door"? yes "could he have survived"? yes. but its not how James Camron wanted to write his story.                   I don't like that jack died, but its not up to me or anyone else. does it make James Camron a bad person for it? NO. death happens, in real life and in stories, but think about it, if no one ever died in a story, it wouldn't be much of a story, it would make it too predictable and no one would be worried that the character might die. unsuspected and tragic deaths add in surprising plot twists that the audience won't expect. that's my view on this debate.

Fifth, the life jacket may affect the door differently on how it was back then

I definitely think it could have turned out differently and Jack didn't have to die...

But there are a lot of things to take into account. The situation here is drastically different than the one in the movie. It was nighttime, they were in the sea surrounded by a ton of thrashing panicking people and noise, they were exhausted, the sea was freezing, they were scared, and they were seventeen-year-old kids. Having likely never been in a crisis situation like that before, and being given no time to prepare themselves beforehand, they acted in the only way their clouded minds could come up with.

There were totally a bunch of alternatives that could've happened. They could have done things that might have seen them both saved. But sadly, we're not gifted with ability of foresight, and the poor things just couldn't think deeply or logically under the stress of the situation.

I get the point of this "theory"... but if you think about the situation that they were in, they'd been running around for about 2 hours trying to get to a lifeboat together, and even longer before that being chased by the security, so they would've been pretty tired. Also, they had been clinging to the top of a sinking boat with so many other people. Obviously it would've been hard to find that door when everyone wanted to find something to stay afloat on. They would've already been in the water for some time. Hypothermia could act quick.
Another point to look at on this is that the water that the two men in the demonstration here is not the same place that Jack and Rose were in, and so making the circumstances different.
If you put them in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean after been chased round for 4 or so hours, maybe I would've been able to believe this but you know, maybe not the most practical of things to do to test a myth.

1.) Salt water vs fresh.
2.) Water temperature and muscle mobility.
3.) Did these two run around for at least 20 minutes prior to tire themselves out like that of someone fleeing a sinking ship?
4.) Relatively calm lake water  vs deep sea ocean
5.) Night vs day (another temperature variable and vision)
6.) Genders
7.) Clothing weight (clothing of the time)
8.) State of mind. Did you just see a bunch of women, children, men drown? Did you outswim a sinking ship that could f dragged you down?
